8th, Nor must we forget the hopefulncss of Bacon asan important clement in his influence. Men who despair of mankind and of the future are, happily, seldom successlul in persuading others to accept their advice or their systems. There is a healthy instinct in man which leads him to believe that the future will be better than the past, and that the labours of the present generation will not be without their effect in improving the condition of the next. No man was ever inspired with this feeling more strongly than Bacon.
